description:
From Middle English megre, from Anglo-Norman megre, Old French maigre, from Latin macer, from Proto-Indo-European *mh₂ḱrós. Akin, through the Indo-European root, to Old English mæġer (“meager, lean”), West Frisian meager (“meager”), Dutch mager (“meager”), German mager, Icelandic magr whence the Icelandic magur,
Norwegian Bokmål mager and Danish mager. Doublet of maigre.

adjectives.description: meager (comparative meagerer, superlative meagerest) (American spelling) (Canadian spelling, common)

entries.meaning: Poor, deficient or inferior in amount, quality or extent
examples: A meager piece of cake in one bite.
The street outside my window furnishes meager entertainment.

entries.meaning: (set theory) Of a set: such that, considered as a subset of a (usually larger) topological space, it is in a precise sense small or negligible.
(mineralogy) Dry and harsh to the touch (e.g., as chalk).

verbs.description: meager (third-person singular simple present meagers, present participle meagering, simple past and past participle meagered)
